Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Giving You "Almost" What You Want - Customizing Products Through the Integration of Market Modeling and Engineering Design

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award is to test the hypothesis that improving the integration of preference modeling and engineering design can lead to customized products better suited to respond to heterogeneous markets and changing needs. While mass customization - providing customers with exactly what they want - has seen significant failures, competitiveness in a global market requires balancing targeted product architectures with consumer-customizable components. Research tasks are identified that will advance how engineers: 1) utilize consumer preferences; 2) manage system flexibility; and 3) implement system reconfigurability. The educational objectives engage in activities that focus on the multidisciplinary, interdisciplinary, and systems-level education of current and future engineers. These objectives are achieved in part by: 1) introducing computer-based multidisciplinary design optimization problems in a pilot study at four high schools; and 2) working toward an undergraduate general education thematic track in interdisciplinary design.

If successful, this research will allow American manufacturing enterprises to identify markets where giving a customer 'almost' what they want - through personalization (done by the manufacturer) and customization (done by the consumer) - can deliver maximum value. Further, by understanding how component properties influence system reconfigurations, viable markets and core technologies for reconfigurability will be defined. The educational objectives will create a design thread that extends from high school through graduate school. Applying multidisciplinary simulations in secondary education is a first step toward producing engineers with interdisciplinary competency, and will be used to promote diversity in engineering by shedding light on today's societal challenges. At the collegiate level, engineering students will get focused exposure to interdisciplinary topics, while students outside of engineering will be exposed to principles of product design. As NC State currently has no engineering classes available for general education credit, this thematic track will have campus-wide effects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objective of this CAREER award focused on understanding how product design decisions could be informed by quantitative customer preference models to create products that offer greater value to consumers. Significant outcomes of this project contribute to our discipline’s ability to design products (and systems) that maximize value to both the consumer and the manufacturer; that is, we are now more effective at defining the right mix of products to offer. This work is important because American manufacturers are competing at a time when product proliferation is not effective, or possible. We explored how the increased consumer value for customized products could be balanced with increased engineering cost to create products that better meet the needs of individual consumers.

 

A driving focus of our effort was exploring different approaches of modeling consumer preference to understand why these models led to different engineering design solutions. We were able to develop an approach that quantified the sacrifice a consumer experienced when they purchased a product not customized to their individual preferences. This metric was used to identify where customization in a product line provided greatest value when compared to a set of mass produced products. Four areas for future mass customization research were also identified: (1) customer needs and preference assessment tools, (2) approaches for requirement specification and conceptual design, (3) insights from methodologies focused on the development of durable MC goods and (4) enhancements in information mapping and handling. We also explored the four Ps of the Marketing Mix: Product, Price, Place and Promotion, and we addressed the need, and research opportunities, that exist as our discipline begins to explore Design for Place and Design for Promotion.

 

We explored the effectiveness of creating product line solutions using different market model formulations in the presence of both compensatory and noncompensatory decision rules. We also quantified the robustness and reliability of a product line solution in the presence of uncertainty associated with the estimated market model. Finally, we explored how customer preference models could be combined with social network theory to model technology diffusion. Our work also explored the engineering ramifications associated with product customization. We successfully integrated engineering change analysis models and customer preference models. We demonstrated how relationships can be constructed between engineering re-work, how those proposed changes propagate throughout the design, and how much customers may be willing to pay for customized good. Because of these efforts, we better understand the relationship between market advantage and the effort required to make product customization / product variety possible.

 

For many of these problems the number of possible outcomes number in the billions of trillions. We identified optimization algorithm advancements that allowed large spaces to be navigated more effectively. Work was also expanded to the design of composite panels, where we demonstrated how the optimal configuration is influenced by the choice of analysis model and the consideration of multiple objectives. Using the approaches developed under this award, run time reductions as large as 80% were demonstrated. We also demonstrated the simulation-based design optimization of a variable geometry spray fuel injector. A multi-objective genetic algorithm was interfaced with commercial computational fluid dynamics software to reveal the inherent tradeoff between actuator stroke and spray angle sensitivity.

 

The educational objectives of this CAREER award integrated preference modeling and engineering design principles into the engineering curriculum at NC State and focused on training current and future engineers. Design topics were infused throughout the aerospace engineering curriculum at NC State, as the PI designed (or help design) two sophomore level class and one senior/graduate level class. We also helped organize a ‘Professionalism in the Workplace’ workshop for students in the MAE department, and the PI runs the department’s undergraduate researcher traineeship. A research traineeship course was also created that has been attended by more than 400 new graduate students.

 

Significant service was also completed for ASME and AIAA, where the PI took on leadership roles within his discipline. The PI was also named the ASME DED Student and Early Career Professionals Chair. A student-focused workshop was created for the ASME IDETC&CIE Conferences that created a forum for students to learn and discuss best research practice. Over 500 students have attended this workshop, to date. Work from this award has also been presented to over 300 market research practitioners.  

 

As part of this award five graduate students (1 PhD, 4 MS) and one undergraduate student were trained at NC State University. Current publication numbers include five journal publications in print, three journal publications under review, eleven conference papers, and five thesis/dissertations. The students trained on this grant now possess expert-level knowledge related to market-driven product design and will hopefully create solutions that offer a greater value to society.
